awd_titl_txt: Understanding How Remote Residues Influence Enzyme Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Christopher Cheatum and his group are using advanced laser spectroscopy techniques to study how distant parts of a protein affect the chemistry that occurs within the active site. This research advances the fundamental understanding of catalysis and the ways that enzymes make use of networks of protein motions in order to achieve high efficiency and selectivity. Such understanding has the potential to support the development of new catalysts for targeted chemical reactivity, as well as the design and optimization of biocatalysts for applications in bioreactors. In addition, Prof. Cheatum and his group are working to extend the capabilities of the laser spectroscopy technique to make it more widely applicable for solving chemical and biochemical problems of broad scientific interest. The students engaged in this research develop skills in molecular biology, computational chemistry, and laser spectroscopy that are important for applications across science and technology, thus preparing them to make critical impacts in the scientific workforce. Professor Cheatum is also engaged in high-impact outreach activities involving K-12 students, and partners with faculty at a local community college in order to involve their students in his research and to encourage those students to pursue science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) careers.

This project addresses fundamental questions about the role of the long-range protein superstructure in enzyme catalyzed reactions: How does the peripheral molecular structure around a catalytic center affect its selectivity and efficiency? How far away from the catalytic center can this influence extend? How can one identify the key residues that modulate the catalyzed reaction dynamics? The central hypothesis of this work is that long-range networks in enzymes dynamically regulate catalysis. Two-dimensional infrared (2D IR) spectroscopy is a powerful tool for probing protein conformational distributions and dynamics, and is the primary tool the team is using to probe the dynamic effects of remote protein residues. The team is working to determine the effects of remote residues on the dynamics of the catalytic center in dihydrofolate reductase, to understand the effects of remote residues involved in the rate-promoting vibration in purine nucleoside phosphorylase, and to identify remote residues that are involved in the active-site structure and reaction dynamics in formate dehydrogenase. Understanding how long-range interactions affect enzyme reactivity has broad impact across many disciplines. Additional broader impacts of the project include the advanced technical training of graduate, undergraduate, and community college students, as well as Prof. Cheatum’s involvement in Skype a Scientist and Data Nuggets programs to share his research with K-12 students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Enzymes are proteins that catalyze chemical reactions, making life possible. They are vital for drug discovery, creating new enzymes with tailored functions, and other life chemistry applications. The link between enzyme structure and chemical function is crucial for these applications. Yet, the role of enzyme movements in this relationship remains a question. Evidence suggests that enzymes evolved to have specific structural folds and to form networks that facilitate function cooperatively. However, methods to identify these networks are insufficient. In our project, we combined computational modeling, functional studies, and protein motion measurements to devise a computational method for identifying networks. We then tested, both computationally and experimentally, if residues in these networks cooperatively affect protein motions and function. Focusing on the model enzyme formate dehydrogenase, we developed methods applicable to other enzymes. We discovered pathways within the enzyme linking to the active site's critical parts, known to be functionally important. We examined both the natural enzyme and its single and double mutant variants. The results indicated that single mutations alter protein motions and function with minimal or no structural changes. Double mutations showed effects beyond additive, indicating cooperative behavior. This method allowed us to pinpoint several cooperative networks within the system. These results provide a systematic method for identifying networks of residues that exhibit cooperative behavior, applicable across various systems. Understanding these cooperative interactions is crucial for grasping the structure-dynamics-function relationship, which is fundamental to drug discovery and the design of functionality in complex enzyme systems.

Beyond its intellectual merit, this project has had significant broader impacts, including the completion of Ph.D. programs for three graduate students who have secured successful job positions, and research opportunities for two undergraduates who have advanced to graduate studies. The Principal Investigator has engaged in outreach through the Skype-a-Scientist program, which links active scientists with classroom teachers to discuss their work with students. Each year of the award, the PI has connected with students to communicate the details of this research and to convey the thrill of scientific discovery.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2024
Modified by: Christopher Cheatum
